## 1. How the research is structured  

| Evidence type | What it can tell us | Typical strengths | Typical weaknesses |
|---------------|--------------------|-------------------|--------------------|
| **International agency assessments** (e.g., IARC, WHO, USDA) | Systematic reviews of all published studies; assign a *hazard classification* (evidence for *causality*). | Broad, transparent, use pre‑defined criteria. | Dependent on quality of underlying studies; classifications are about *hazard* (possibility of causing disease), not *risk* (how big the effect is in a real diet). |
| **Prospective cohort studies** (e.g., EPIC, NHS, HPFS, US NIH‑AARP) | Track large numbers of people over years, relate baseline diet to later cancer incidence. | Large sample sizes, ability to adjust for many confounders, temporal direction (diet → disease). | Observational only – cannot prove causation; measurement error in diet questionnaires; residual confounding (e.g., lifestyle, genetics). |
| **Case‑control studies** | Compare past diet of people with cancer (cases) to similar people without cancer (controls). | Efficient for rare cancers; can collect detailed dietary data. | Recall bias (cases may remember diet differently); selection bias. |
| **Meta‑analyses & pooled analyses** | Combine results from many studies to increase statistical power and examine dose‑response. | More precise estimates; can test heterogeneity across populations. | Quality depends on included studies; publication bias can inflate effects. |
| **Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)** (very few) | Randomly assign participants to different diets or meat‑substitution interventions. | Gold‑standard for causality. | Short duration, small sample size, ethical limits on long‑term cancer outcomes; most RCTs focus on intermediate biomarkers (e.g., colonocyte DNA damage) rather than cancer itself. |
| **Mechanistic/experimental studies** (cell culture, animal models) | Test biological pathways (e.g., formation of carcinogenic compounds). | Provide plausible *biological* explanations. | May not translate directly to human diet levels. |
